title: Mother-of-three, 33, shares her foolproof trick for stopping kids' tantrums in their tracks
text:
A mother-of-three children under the age of five has shared her foolproof trick for coping with moody kids and stopping tantrums before they escalate.

Laura Mazza, 33, a parenting blogger and social worker from Melbourne, recently revealed her eldest son Luca planned to 'run away' after she told him to read a book instead of playing on his iPad all day.

After losing her temper in a moment of frustration, Laura used reverse psychology to reassure the little boy by telling him everything she would miss about him if he left - a clever tactic that quickly made him relent.

'Luca told me I was the worst mum,' Laura captioned her post.

Melbourne-based parenting blogger Laura Mazza (pictured) has revealed how reassurance is the key to coping with moody children

The mother-of-three used reverse psychology and reassurance to diffuse a tantrum from her eldest son Luca (pictured second from right)

The tantrum started when Laura sternly forbid her son from sitting on his iPad all day.

She recalled how he produced a real estate brochure in response, declaring: 'I'm going to move here, far, far away! I'm gonna run away!'

'He was at the door and looked at me with sad little eyes, and I took a deep breath and reminded myself of the emotions inside that little heart of his,' she wrote.

Collecting herself, Laura caught her son off guard by pretending to agree - but not before explaining how much she would miss him.

'He wasn't expecting the response and looked at me confused, but quickly said 'I don't care!'

'I said 'Okay, but I'll miss making you peanut butter and jam sandwiches, and I'll miss giving you big cuddles in the morning, and letting you dunk biscuits in my tea... and I'll miss tickling you and dancing with you. I'll miss your big smile and your big heart.'

Laura convinced her young son to calm down and forget his plans to run away from home by telling him how much she would miss him

Laura's reassurance worked and Luca agreed to stay, but 'only because she would miss him so much'.

The post quickly racked up almost 3,000 likes and hundreds of comments from fellow parents praising her approach.

'That's gold! What a beautiful relationship you have, pat yourself on the back,' someone wrote.

'I love this. Well done for reacting with love and compassion - it's the hardest thing to do but absolutely the best way,' another said.
description: Australian parenting blogger and mum-of-three Laura Mazza, 33, recently revealed how she uses reverse psychology to cope with her children's moods and stop tantrums before they escalate.
authors: Alice Murphy For Daily Mail Australia
